Text Mining of Permanent Downhole Gauges

Vignette Author

2017-10-16

library(petro.One)
library(tm)
## Loading required package: NLP
my_url <- make_search_url(query = "Permanent Downhole Gauge", 
                          how = "all")        

get_papers_count(my_url)    # how many papers total
## [1] 525
papers_by_type(my_url)      # papers by type
## # A tibble: 3 x 2
##               name value
##              <chr> <dbl>
## 1 Conference paper   445
## 2    Journal paper    76
## 3     Presentation     4
# create a dataframe of papers found
df <- read_multidoc(my_url)
df
## # A tibble: 525 x 6
##                                                                     title_data
##                                                                          <chr>
##  1              Encouraging Experience in the Use of Permanent Downhole Gauges
##  2                               Permanent Downhole Gauge: A Need or A Luxury?
##  3    Comparative Analysis of Permanent Downhole Gauges and their Applications
##  4       Reservoir Management Optimization Using Permanent Downhole Gauge Data
##  5          Pressure Transient Analysis Of Data From Permanent Downhole Gauges
##  6                          Wavelet Filtering of Permanent Downhole Gauge Data
##  7             Permanent Downhole Gauges: A Key To Optimize Deepsea Production
##  8        Recurrent Neural Networks for Permanent Downhole Gauge Data Analysis
##  9 Analysis of Permanent Downhole Gauge Data by Cointerpretation of Simultaneo
## 10  Analysis of Well Test Data From Permanent Downhole Gauges by Deconvolution
## # ... with 515 more rows, and 5 more variables: paper_id <chr>,
## #   source <chr>, type <chr>, year <int>, author1_data <chr>
library(petro.One)

plot_wordcloud(term_freq, min.freq = 20)

Bar plot

plot_bars(term_freq, min.freq = 25)

dendogram

plot_relationships(df, min.freq = 30, threshold = 0.1)

library(cluster)   
tdm <- get_term_document_matrix(df)$tdm

tdm.rst <- removeSparseTerms(tdm, 0.93)

d <- dist(tdm.rst, method="euclidian")   
fit <- hclust(d=d, method="complete")   # for a different look try substituting: method="ward.D"
fit 
## 
## Call:
## hclust(d = d, method = "complete")
## 
## Cluster method   : complete 
## Distance         : euclidean 
## Number of objects: 16
plot(fit, hang = 1)

  • dendogram
